title: Trove of spices from around the world found on sunken fifteenth-century Norse ship

last_post.content:
"Trove of spices from around the world found on sunken fifteenth-century Norse ship"

"A pair of archaeologists with Lund University in Sweden has found "a treasure trove" of plants aboard a sunken 15th-century #Norse ship. Mikael Larsson and Brendan Foley describe their findings in PLOS ONE.

The researchers found spices such as nutmeg, cloves, mustard and dill. They also found samples of other plant material, such as saffron and ginger, peppercorns and almonds. Some of the spices would have come from as far away as Indonesia, suggesting that King Hans had developed an advanced trade network. The researchers also found snack items, such as dried blackberries, raspberries, grapes and flax, each find showing just how rich and powerful Hans had become. The researchers also found one non-edible plant, henbane, which, in the past, was used for medicinal purposes."

@histodons #RespectfortheAncestors #Norway #archeology

https://phys.org/news/2023-02-trove-spices-world-sunken-fifteenth-century.html

title: Cherry blossom phenology and temperature reconstructions at Kyoto | 生態気象学研究グループ

last_post.content:
Cherry tree flowering dates from Kyoto City. Data go back to the year 812.

2021 saw the earliest flowering date in over 1,200 years with full flowering on 26 March.

Recent changes reflect both climate change and urban development.

Data: http://atmenv.envi.osakafu-u.ac.jp/aono/kyophenotemp4/

Attribution: https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/about-us/press-office/news/weather-and-climate/2022/kyoto-cherry-blossom-dates-shifted-by-human-influence

Sorry, but fuck CWs for this post.

I spent part of the afternoon here crying and talking to my bestie as news hit about the bullying murdered trans girl Brianna Ghey had been subjected to.

I left school 30 years ago. I've been in therapy, and I still fall apart when I hear a story of long-term bullying similar to mine where cops & school were absolutely useless and probably made the situation much worse by their inaction. Abusers become more smug when they sense they have impunity.

Thankful that the violence I incurred from my attackers didn't kill my "sissy, fag, poof, girl" body, but I sure have plenty of scars in my mind, and damn it still triggers me to fall apart and regress back to that scared child and teen.

Justice for #BriannaGhey

#transmisogyny #violence #transviolence #transphobia #hatecrime

I left school 30 years ago. I've been in therapy, and I still fall apart when I hear a story of long-term bullying similar to mine where cops & school were absolutely useless and probably made the situation much worse by their inaction. Abusers become more smug when they sense they have impunity.

Thankful that the violence I incurred from my attackers didn't kill my "sissy, fag, poof, girl" body, but I sure have plenty of scars in my mind, and damn it still triggers me to fall apart and regress back to that scared child and teen.

Justice for #BriannaGhey

#transmisogyny #violence #transviolence #transphobia #hatecrime

title: This Tool Could Protect Artists From A.I. Image Generators

last_post.content: The artist revolt against AI-powered art generators is in full swing. Artists have filed a class-action lawsuit in California against Stability AI and Midjourney. They've raised money for a D.C. lobbyist. And soon they will have a technological countermeasure, a tool designed by U of Chicago computer scientists that will "cloak" art posted online so that it won't be "feeding this monster that becomes more and more like them." My latest: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/13/technology/ai-art-generator-lensa-stable-diffusion.html

title: Stop the peer-review treadmill. I want to get off

last_post.content:
Bad, but not as bad as the peer review crisis anecdotes that make it into tweets and toots had suggested to me:
“On Clarivate’s ScholarOne, a manuscript-tracking platform that helps to organize reviews for more than 8,000 academic journals, the average rate at which scientists accept a review dropped from 37.5% in 2020 to 32.3% in 2022.”

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00403-8

Stop the peer-review treadmill. I want to get off https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-00403-8

Informative piece on the overburdened peer review system.

Happy to see discussion of preprint review: "Rebeccah Lijek ... directs her reviewing energies to preprints ... She loves being able to consider the science just on its merits, without judging whether a study is original enough to deserve publication by a specific journal. She finds the process more collegial and has made new connections and friends through it."

title: How To Easily Find Your Twitter Network on Mastodon - STILL WORKING!

last_post.content:
TRYING TO FIND YOUR OLD TWITTER NETWORK?

After the great API shutoff, a lot of the services that people have been utilising to find their old Twitter networks no longer work.

Fedifinder is one of the few that is still up and running (I confirmed it myself this morning).

It isn't as seamless as some of the older methods, but can still be used in mere minutues to find users and easily follow them on Mastodon using the Import feature.

This video guide walks through the whole process from start to finish.

Please #Boost this to spread the word around your networks as much as possible. :ablobcatbongopost:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=37S246Wr_JE

#Fedifinder #MastodonTips #FediTips #TwitterMigration #Twitter

General-purpose AI (GPAI) models are designed to have numerous applications. They can be used in standalone systems or as the ‘building block’ for hundreds of other AI systems.

In our latest blog, Sabrina Küspert (University of Oxford), Nicolas Moës (The Future Society) and Connor Dunlop (Ada) examine how GPAI models are being released into the market, and the implications for the EU AI Act. They identify five key challenges for policymakers.

title: Machine Reading, Fast and Slow: When Do Models "Understand" Language?

last_post.content:
New BIML Bibliography entry #MLsec

https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.07430

Choudhury, et al

Machine Reading, Fast and Slow: When Do Models "Understand" Language?

This paper is stuck in the mud of cognitive psychology. The LLMs are dated and thus not as relevant as they could be. The probes don’t really get to the nature of understanding. We had high hopes for this work, but they were dashed.

See https://berryvilleiml.com/references/

title: Lyft’s Huge Earnings Hit Spurred by SEC Accounting Warning (2)

last_post.content:
I should understand this better but it's really interesting how the SEC will consider adjusted GAAP to be misleading sometimes even if presented alongside GAAP figures. It's not a prominence thing; it's an implicit statement that disclosure isn't enough.

https://news.bloomberglaw.com/securities-law/lyfts-massive-earnings-hit-spurred-by-sec-accounting-warning

Sensitive #mentalhealth data is for sale by little-known data brokers, at times for a few hundred dollars and with little effort to hide personal information such as names and addresses (#PII), according to research
Duke University report found 11 data brokers agreed to sell information that identified people by issues, including #depression, #anxiety and #bipolar disorder and often sorted them by #demographic information.
